alert.note: Alert for Caroline; Charles City; Chesterfield; City of Richmond; Goochland; Hanover; Henrico; King William; King and Queen; New Kent; Powhatan (Virginia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wakefield (Eastern Virginia and Southern Maryland)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued September 23 at 4:19PM EDT until September 23 at 10:15PM EDT by NWS Wakefield
info.description: The National Weather Service in Wakefield has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Northwestern Chesterfield County in central Virginia... Southeastern Goochland County in central Virginia... Hanover County in central Virginia... Henrico County in central Virginia... Eastern Powhatan County in central Virginia... The City of Richmond in central Virginia... Central Charles City County in east central Virginia... Northwestern King and Queen County in east central Virginia... King William County in east central Virginia... New Kent County in east central Virginia... Southeastern Caroline County in north central Virginia... * Until 1015 PM EDT. * At 419 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain across the warned area. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by heavy rain. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Richmond, Powhatan, Goochland, New Kent, King William, Ashland, Mechanicsville, Highland Springs, Virginia Union University, Virginia Commonwealth University, Downtown Richmond, Randolph Macon College, University Of Richmond, Tuckahoe, Bon Air, Roxbury, Talleysville, Saint Stephens Church, King And Queen Court House and Hanover. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
